projectDesc.p: This version of the Folger Digital Texts uses TEI Simple to encode the Shakespeare texts edited by Barbara Mowat and Paul Werstine. The major goal of recasting the texts in this manner is to make them interoperable with a large corpus of early modern texts derived from the EEBO-TCP transcriptions and encoded in TEI Simple with linguistic annotation.

For a full description of the encoding practices of the Folger Digital Texts consult their encodingDesc section. This version is completely faithful to the readings, orthogrgraphy, and punctuation of the source text. It uses a different XML encoding scheme, with occasional losses in expressiveness. The major differences are:
Number div are replaced by unnumbered divs
Lines of verse are marked in l, tags, lines of prose in ab
All xml:ids are corpuswide identifiers
Information from the participant description element particDesc in the teiHeader has been moved into a castList element in the front element
Each spoken word in the text has been linguistically annotated with a lemma and POS tag

refsDecl.p: Words, spaces, and punctuation characters are numbered sequentially, incremented by 10.

Most other elements begin with an element-specific prefix, followed by a reference to the Folger Through Line Number, a sequential numbering of the numbered lines in the text. If an element is inline with play text, it has the same line number as the line where it begins. If it begins on a line following play text, a decimal number is appended and incremented as necessary. If it falls between a speech prefix and the play text, a ".0" is appended to the value of the following line number.

personGrp.name: Lords, Sailors, Musicians, and other Attendants

castItem.roleDesc: a lady of Messaline shipwrecked on the coast of Illyria(later disguised as Cesario)

castGroup.head: Lords, Sailors, Musicians, and other Attendants

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Orsino, Duke of Illyria, Curio, and other Lords, with Musicians playing.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: If music be the food of love, play on.
Give me excess of it, that, surfeiting,
The appetite may sicken and so die.
That strain again! It had a dying fall.
O, it came o’er my ear like the sweet sound
That breathes upon a bank of violets,
Stealing and giving odor. Enough; no more.
’Tis not so sweet now as it was before.
O spirit of love, how quick and fresh art thou,
That, notwithstanding thy capacity
Receiveth as the sea, naught enters there,
Of what validity and pitch soe’er,
But falls into abatement and low price
Even in a minute. So full of shapes is fancy
That it alone is high fantastical.

sp.speaker: CURIO
sp.l: Will you go hunt, my lord?

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: What, Curio?

sp.speaker: CURIO
sp.l: The hart.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: Why, so I do, the noblest that I have.
O, when mine eyes did see Olivia first,
Methought she purged the air of pestilence.
That instant was I turned into a hart,
And my desires, like fell and cruel hounds,
E’er since pursue me.
How now, what news from her?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.l: So please my lord, I might not be admitted,
But from her handmaid do return this answer:
The element itself, till seven years’ heat,
Shall not behold her face at ample view,
But like a cloistress she will veilèd walk,
And water once a day her chamber round
With eye-offending brine— all this to season
A brother’s dead love, which she would keep fresh
And lasting in her sad remembrance.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: O, she that hath a heart of that fine frame
To pay this debt of love but to a brother,
How will she love when the rich golden shaft
Hath killed the flock of all affections else
That live in her; when liver, brain, and heart,
These sovereign thrones, are all supplied, and filled
Her sweet perfections with one self king!
Away before me to sweet beds of flowers!
Love thoughts lie rich when canopied with bowers.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter Viola, a Captain, and Sailors.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: What country, friends, is this?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.l: This is Illyria, lady.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: And what should I do in Illyria?
My brother he is in Elysium.
Perchance he is not drowned.— What think you, sailors?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.l: It is perchance that you yourself were saved.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: O, my poor brother! And so perchance may he be.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.l: True, madam. And to comfort you with chance,
Assure yourself, after our ship did split,
When you and those poor number saved with you
Hung on our driving boat, I saw your brother,
Most provident in peril, bind himself
( Courage and hope both teaching him the practice)
To a strong mast that lived upon the sea,
Where, like Arion on the dolphin’s back,
I saw him hold acquaintance with the waves
So long as I could see.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: For saying so, there’s gold.
Mine own escape unfoldeth to my hope,
Whereto thy speech serves for authority,
The like of him. Know’st thou this country?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.l: Ay, madam, well, for I was bred and born
Not three hours’ travel from this very place.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: Who governs here?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.l: A noble duke, in nature as in name.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: What is his name?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.l: Orsino.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: Orsino. I have heard my father name him.
He was a bachelor then.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.l: And so is now, or was so very late;
For but a month ago I went from hence,
And then ’twas fresh in murmur ( as, you know,
What great ones do the less will prattle of)
That he did seek the love of fair Olivia.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: What’s she?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.l: A virtuous maid, the daughter of a count
That died some twelvemonth since, then leaving her
In the protection of his son, her brother,
Who shortly also died, for whose dear love,
They say, she hath abjured the sight
And company of men.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: O, that I served that lady,
And might not be delivered to the world
Till I had made mine own occasion mellow,
What my estate is.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.l: That were hard to compass
Because she will admit no kind of suit,
No, not the Duke’s.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: There is a fair behavior in thee, captain,
And though that nature with a beauteous wall
Doth oft close in pollution, yet of thee
I will believe thou hast a mind that suits
With this thy fair and outward character.
I prithee— and I’ll pay thee bounteously—
Conceal me what I am, and be my aid
For such disguise as haply shall become
The form of my intent. I’ll serve this duke.
Thou shalt present me as an eunuch to him.
It may be worth thy pains, for I can sing
And speak to him in many sorts of music
That will allow me very worth his service.
What else may hap, to time I will commit.
Only shape thou thy silence to my wit.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.l: Be you his eunuch, and your mute I’ll be.
When my tongue blabs, then let mine eyes not see.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: I thank thee. Lead me on.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
What a plague means my niece to take the death
of her brother thus? I am sure care’s an enemy to
life.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
By my troth, Sir Toby, you must come in earlier
o’ nights. Your cousin, my lady, takes great exceptions
to your ill hours.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Why, let her except before excepted!

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
Ay, but you must confine yourself within the
modest limits of order.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Confine? I’ll confine myself no finer than I am.
These clothes are good enough to drink in, and so
be these boots too. An they be not, let them hang
themselves in their own straps!

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
That quaffing and drinking will undo you. I
heard my lady talk of it yesterday, and of a foolish
knight that you brought in one night here to be her
wooer.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: Ay, he.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: He’s as tall a man as any ’s in Illyria.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: What’s that to th’ purpose?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Why, he has three thousand ducats a year!

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
Ay, but he’ll have but a year in all these ducats.
He’s a very fool and a prodigal.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Fie that you’ll say so! He plays o’ th’ viol-de-gamboys
and speaks three or four languages word
for word without book, and hath all the good gifts of
nature.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
He hath indeed, almost natural, for, besides
that he’s a fool, he’s a great quarreler, and, but that
he hath the gift of a coward to allay the gust he hath
in quarreling, ’tis thought among the prudent he
would quickly have the gift of a grave.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
By this hand, they are scoundrels and substractors
that say so of him. Who are they?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
They that add, moreover, he’s drunk nightly in
your company.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
With drinking healths to my niece. I’ll drink to
her as long as there is a passage in my throat and
drink in Illyria. He’s a coward and a coistrel that
will not drink to my niece till his brains turn o’ th’
toe like a parish top. What, wench! Castiliano vulgo,
for here comes Sir Andrew Agueface.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Sir Toby Belch! How now, Sir Toby Belch?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Sweet Sir Andrew!

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Bless you, fair shrew.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: And you too, sir.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Accost, Sir Andrew, accost!

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: What’s that?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: My niece’s chambermaid.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
Good Mistress Accost, I desire better
acquaintance.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: My name is Mary, sir.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Good Mistress Mary Accost—

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
You mistake, knight. “ Accost” is front her, board
her, woo her, assail her.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
By my troth, I would not undertake her in
this company. Is that the meaning of “ accost”?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: Fare you well, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
An thou let part so, Sir Andrew, would thou
mightst never draw sword again.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
An you part so, mistress, I would I might
never draw sword again. Fair lady, do you think you
have fools in hand?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: Sir, I have not you by th’ hand.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
Marry, but you shall have, and here’s my
hand.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
Now sir, thought is free. I
pray you, bring your hand to th’ butt’ry bar and let
it drink.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
Wherefore, sweetheart? What’s your
metaphor?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: It’s dry, sir.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
Why, I think so. I am not such an ass but I
can keep my hand dry. But what’s your jest?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: A dry jest, sir.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Are you full of them?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
Ay, sir, I have them at my fingers’ ends. Marry,
now I let go your hand, I am barren.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
O knight, thou lack’st a cup of canary! When did
I see thee so put down?

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
Never in your life, I think, unless you see
canary put me down. Methinks sometimes I have
no more wit than a Christian or an ordinary man
has. But I am a great eater of beef, and I believe that
does harm to my wit.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: No question.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
An I thought that, I’d forswear it. I’ll ride
home tomorrow, Sir Toby.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Pourquoi, my dear knight?

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
What is “ pourquoi”? Do, or not do? I would I
had bestowed that time in the tongues that I have in
fencing, dancing, and bearbaiting. O, had I but
followed the arts!

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Then hadst thou had an excellent head of hair.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Why, would that have mended my hair?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Past question, for thou seest it will not curl by
nature.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: But it becomes me well enough, does ’t not?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Excellent! It hangs like flax on a distaff, and I
hope to see a huswife take thee between her legs
and spin it off.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
Faith, I’ll home tomorrow, Sir Toby. Your
niece will not be seen, or if she be, it’s four to one
she’ll none of me. The Count himself here hard by
woos her.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
She’ll none o’ th’ Count. She’ll not match above
her degree, neither in estate, years, nor wit. I have
heard her swear ’t. Tut, there’s life in ’t, man.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
I’ll stay a month longer. I am a fellow o’ th’
strangest mind i’ th’ world. I delight in masques
and revels sometimes altogether.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Art thou good at these kickshawses, knight?

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
As any man in Illyria, whatsoever he be,
under the degree of my betters, and yet I will not
compare with an old man.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: What is thy excellence in a galliard, knight?

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Faith, I can cut a caper.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: And I can cut the mutton to ’t.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
And I think I have the back-trick simply as
strong as any man in Illyria.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Wherefore are these things hid? Wherefore have
these gifts a curtain before ’em? Are they like to
take dust, like Mistress Mall’s picture? Why dost
thou not go to church in a galliard and come home
in a coranto? My very walk should be a jig. I would
not so much as make water but in a sink-a-pace.
What dost thou mean? Is it a world to hide virtues
in? I did think, by the excellent constitution of thy
leg, it was formed under the star of a galliard.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
Ay, ’tis strong, and it does indifferent well in a
dun-colored stock. Shall we set about some
revels?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
What shall we do else? Were we not born under
Taurus?

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Taurus? That’s sides and heart.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
No, sir, it is legs and thighs. Let me see thee
caper. Sir Andrew dances. Ha, higher! Ha, ha,
excellent!

div.head: Scene 4
div.stage: Enter Valentine, and Viola in man’s attire as Cesario.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
If the Duke continue these favors towards
you, Cesario, you are like to be much advanced. He
hath known you but three days, and already you
are no stranger.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
You either fear his humor or my negligence, that
you call in question the continuance of his love. Is
he inconstant, sir, in his favors?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: No, believe me.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: I thank you.
sp.l: Here comes the Count.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: Who saw Cesario, ho?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: On your attendance, my lord, here.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: Stand you awhile aloof.— Cesario,
Thou know’st no less but all. I have unclasped
To thee the book even of my secret soul.
Therefore, good youth, address thy gait unto her.
Be not denied access. Stand at her doors
And tell them, there thy fixèd foot shall grow
Till thou have audience.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: Sure, my noble lord,
If she be so abandoned to her sorrow
As it is spoke, she never will admit me.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: Be clamorous and leap all civil bounds
Rather than make unprofited return.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: Say I do speak with her, my lord, what then?

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: O, then unfold the passion of my love.
Surprise her with discourse of my dear faith.
It shall become thee well to act my woes.
She will attend it better in thy youth
Than in a nuncio’s of more grave aspect.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: I think not so, my lord.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: Dear lad, believe it;
For they shall yet belie thy happy years
That say thou art a man. Diana’s lip
Is not more smooth and rubious, thy small pipe
Is as the maiden’s organ, shrill and sound,
And all is semblative a womans part.
I know thy constellation is right apt
For this affair.— Some four or five attend him,
All, if you will, for I myself am best
When least in company.— Prosper well in this
And thou shalt live as freely as thy lord,
To call his fortunes thine.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: I’ll do my best
To woo your lady. Aside. Yet a barful strife!
Whoe’er I woo, myself would be his wife.

div.head: Scene 5
div.stage: Enter Maria and Feste, the Fool.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
Nay, either tell me where thou hast been, or I
will not open my lips so wide as a bristle may enter
in way of thy excuse. My lady will hang thee for thy
absence.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Let her hang me. He that is well hanged in this
world needs to fear no colors.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: Make that good.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: He shall see none to fear.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
A good Lenten answer. I can tell thee where
that saying was born, of “ I fear no colors.”

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: Where, good Mistress Mary?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
In the wars; and that may you be bold to say in
your foolery.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Well, God give them wisdom that have it, and
those that are Fools, let them use their talents.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
Yet you will be hanged for being so long absent.
Or to be turned away, is not that as good as a
hanging to you?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Many a good hanging prevents a bad marriage,
and, for turning away, let summer bear it out.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: You are resolute, then?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: Not so, neither, but I am resolved on two points.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
That if one break, the other will hold, or if both
break, your gaskins fall.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Apt, in good faith, very apt. Well, go thy way. If Sir
Toby would leave drinking, thou wert as witty a
piece of Eve’s flesh as any in Illyria.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
Peace, you rogue. No more o’ that. Here comes
my lady. Make your excuse wisely, you were best.

div.stage: Enter Lady Olivia with Malvolio and Attendants.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Wit, an ’t be thy will, put me into good
fooling! Those wits that think they have thee do very
oft prove fools, and I that am sure I lack thee may
pass for a wise man. For what says Quinapalus?
“ Better a witty Fool than a foolish wit.”— God bless
thee, lady!

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Take the Fool away.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: Do you not hear, fellows? Take away the Lady.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
Go to, you’re a dry Fool. I’ll no more of you.
Besides, you grow dishonest.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Two faults, madonna, that drink and good counsel
will amend. For give the dry Fool drink, then is
the Fool not dry. Bid the dishonest man mend
himself; if he mend, he is no longer dishonest; if he
cannot, let the botcher mend him. Anything that’s
mended is but patched; virtue that transgresses is
but patched with sin, and sin that amends is but
patched with virtue. If that this simple syllogism
will serve, so; if it will not, what remedy? As there is
no true cuckold but calamity, so beauty’s a flower.
The Lady bade take away the Fool. Therefore, I say
again, take her away.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Sir, I bade them take away you.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Misprision in the highest degree! Lady, cucullus
non facit monachum. That’s as much to say as, I
wear not motley in my brain. Good madonna, give
me leave to prove you a fool.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Can you do it?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: Dexteriously, good madonna.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Make your proof.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
I must catechize you for it, madonna. Good my
mouse of virtue, answer me.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
Well, sir, for want of other idleness, I’ll bide
your proof.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: Good madonna, why mourn’st thou?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Good Fool, for my brother’s death.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: I think his soul is in hell, madonna.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: I know his soul is in heaven, Fool.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
The more fool, madonna, to mourn for your
brother’s soul, being in heaven. Take away the fool,
gentlemen.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
What think you of this Fool, Malvolio? Doth he
not mend?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
Yes, and shall do till the pangs of death
shake him. Infirmity, that decays the wise, doth
ever make the better Fool.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
God send you, sir, a speedy infirmity, for the
better increasing your folly! Sir Toby will be sworn
that I am no fox, but he will not pass his word for
twopence that you are no fool.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: How say you to that, Malvolio?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
I marvel your Ladyship takes delight in
such a barren rascal. I saw him put down the other
day with an ordinary fool that has no more brain
than a stone. Look you now, he’s out of his guard
already. Unless you laugh and minister occasion to
him, he is gagged. I protest I take these wise men
that crow so at these set kind of Fools no better than
the Fools’ zanies.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
O, you are sick of self-love, Malvolio, and taste
with a distempered appetite. To be generous, guiltless,
and of free disposition is to take those things
for bird-bolts that you deem cannon bullets. There
is no slander in an allowed Fool, though he do
nothing but rail; nor no railing in a known discreet
man, though he do nothing but reprove.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Now Mercury endue thee with leasing, for thou
speak’st well of Fools!

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
Madam, there is at the gate a young gentleman
much desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: From the Count Orsino, is it?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
I know not, madam. ’Tis a fair young man, and
well attended.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Who of my people hold him in delay?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: Sir Toby, madam, your kinsman.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
Fetch him off, I pray you. He speaks nothing
but madman. Fie on him! Maria exits. Go you,
Malvolio. If it be a suit from the Count, I am sick,
or not at home; what you will, to dismiss it.

Now you see, sir, how your fooling
grows old, and people dislike it.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Thou hast spoke for us, madonna, as if thy eldest
son should be a Fool, whose skull Jove cram with
brains, for— here he comes— one of thy kin has a
most weak pia mater.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
By mine honor, half drunk!— What is he at the
gate, cousin?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: A gentleman.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: A gentleman? What gentleman?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
’Tis a gentleman here— a plague o’ these pickle
herring!— How now, sot?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: Good Sir Toby.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
Cousin, cousin, how have you come so early by
this lethargy?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Lechery? I defy lechery. There’s one at the gate.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Ay, marry, what is he?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Let him be the devil an he will, I care not. Give
me faith, say I. Well, it’s all one.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: What’s a drunken man like, Fool?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Like a drowned man, a fool, and a madman. One
draught above heat makes him a fool, the second
mads him, and a third drowns him.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
Go thou and seek the crowner and let him sit o’
my coz, for he’s in the third degree of drink: he’s
drowned. Go look after him.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
He is but mad yet, madonna, and the Fool shall
look to the madman.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
Madam, yond young fellow swears he will
speak with you. I told him you were sick; he takes
on him to understand so much, and therefore
comes to speak with you. I told him you were
asleep; he seems to have a foreknowledge of that
too, and therefore comes to speak with you. What is
to be said to him, lady? He’s fortified against any
denial.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Tell him he shall not speak with me.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
Has been told so, and he says he’ll stand at
your door like a sheriff’s post and be the supporter
to a bench, but he’ll speak with you.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: What kind o’ man is he?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p: Why, of mankind.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: What manner of man?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
Of very ill manner. He’ll speak with you,
will you or no.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Of what personage and years is he?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
Not yet old enough for a man, nor young
enough for a boy— as a squash is before ’tis a
peascod, or a codling when ’tis almost an apple. ’Tis
with him in standing water, between boy and man.
He is very well-favored, and he speaks very shrewishly.
One would think his mother’s milk were
scarce out of him.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: Let him approach. Call in my gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p: Gentlewoman, my lady calls.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: Give me my veil. Come, throw it o’er my face.
We’ll once more hear Orsino’s embassy.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: The honorable lady of the house, which is she?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Speak to me. I shall answer for her. Your will?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
Most radiant, exquisite, and unmatchable
beauty— I pray you, tell me if this be the lady of the
house, for I never saw her. I would be loath to cast
away my speech, for, besides that it is excellently
well penned, I have taken great pains to con it. Good
beauties, let me sustain no scorn. I am very comptible
even to the least sinister usage.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Whence came you, sir?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
I can say little more than I have studied, and
that question’s out of my part. Good gentle one,
give me modest assurance if you be the lady of the
house, that I may proceed in my speech.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Are you a comedian?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
No, my profound heart. And yet by the very
fangs of malice I swear I am not that I play. Are
you the lady of the house?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: If I do not usurp myself, I am.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
Most certain, if you are she, you do usurp
yourself, for what is yours to bestow is not yours to
reserve. But this is from my commission. I will on
with my speech in your praise and then show you
the heart of my message.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
Come to what is important in ’t. I forgive you
the praise.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
Alas, I took great pains to study it, and ’tis
poetical.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
It is the more like to be feigned. I pray you,
keep it in. I heard you were saucy at my gates, and
allowed your approach rather to wonder at you than
to hear you. If you be not mad, begone; if you have
reason, be brief. ’Tis not that time of moon with me
to make one in so skipping a dialogue.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: Will you hoist sail, sir? Here lies your way.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
No, good swabber, I am to hull here a little
longer.— Some mollification for your giant, sweet
lady.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Tell me your mind.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: I am a messenger.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
Sure you have some hideous matter to deliver
when the courtesy of it is so fearful. Speak your
office.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
It alone concerns your ear. I bring no overture
of war, no taxation of homage. I hold the olive in
my hand. My words are as full of peace as matter.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
Yet you began rudely. What are you? What
would you?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
The rudeness that hath appeared in me have I
learned from my entertainment. What I am and
what I would are as secret as maidenhead: to your
ears, divinity; to any other’s, profanation.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
Give us the place alone. We will hear this
divinity. Maria and Attendants exit. Now, sir, what
is your text?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: Most sweet lady—

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
A comfortable doctrine, and much may be said
of it. Where lies your text?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: In Orsino’s bosom.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: In his bosom? In what chapter of his bosom?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: To answer by the method, in the first of his heart.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
O, I have read it; it is heresy. Have you no more
to say?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: Good madam, let me see your face.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
Have you any commission from your lord to
negotiate with my face? You are now out of your
text. But we will draw the curtain and show you the
picture. She removes her veil. Look you, sir, such a
one I was this present. Is ’t not well done?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: Excellently done, if God did all.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
’Tis in grain, sir; ’twill endure wind and
weather.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: ’Tis beauty truly blent, whose red and white
Nature’s own sweet and cunning hand laid on.
Lady, you are the cruel’st she alive
If you will lead these graces to the grave
And leave the world no copy.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
O, sir, I will not be so hard-hearted! I will give
out divers schedules of my beauty. It shall be
inventoried and every particle and utensil labeled
to my will: as, item, two lips indifferent red; item,
two gray eyes with lids to them; item, one neck, one
chin, and so forth. Were you sent hither to praise
me?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: I see you what you are. You are too proud.
But if you were the devil you are fair.
My lord and master loves you. O, such love
Could be but recompensed though you were crowned
The nonpareil of beauty.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: How does he love me?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: With adorations, fertile tears,
With groans that thunder love, with sighs of fire.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: Your lord does know my mind. I cannot love him.
Yet I suppose him virtuous, know him noble,
Of great estate, of fresh and stainless youth;
In voices well divulged, free, learned, and valiant,
And in dimension and the shape of nature
A gracious person. But yet I cannot love him.
He might have took his answer long ago.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: If I did love you in my master’s flame,
With such a suff’ring, such a deadly life,
In your denial I would find no sense.
I would not understand it.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: Why, what would you?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: Make me a willow cabin at your gate
And call upon my soul within the house,
Write loyal cantons of contemnèd love
And sing them loud even in the dead of night,
Hallow your name to the reverberate hills
And make the babbling gossip of the air
Cry out “ Olivia!” O, you should not rest
Between the elements of air and earth
But you should pity me.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: You might do much.
What is your parentage?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: Above my fortunes, yet my state is well.
I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: Get you to your lord.
I cannot love him. Let him send no more—
Unless perchance you come to me again
To tell me how he takes it. Fare you well.
I thank you for your pains. Spend this for me.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: I am no fee’d post, lady. Keep your purse.
My master, not myself, lacks recompense.
Love make his heart of flint that you shall love,
And let your fervor, like my master’s, be
Placed in contempt. Farewell, fair cruelty.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: “ What is your parentage?”
“ Above my fortunes, yet my state is well.
I am a gentleman.” I’ll be sworn thou art.
Thy tongue, thy face, thy limbs, actions, and spirit
Do give thee fivefold blazon. Not too fast! Soft, soft!
Unless the master were the man. How now?
Even so quickly may one catch the plague?
Methinks I feel this youth’s perfections
With an invisible and subtle stealth
To creep in at mine eyes. Well, let it be.—
What ho, Malvolio!

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.l: Here, madam, at your service.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: Run after that same peevish messenger,
The County’s man. He left this ring behind him,
Would I or not. Tell him I’ll none of it.
Desire him not to flatter with his lord,
Nor hold him up with hopes. I am not for him.
If that the youth will come this way tomorrow,
I’ll give him reasons for ’t. Hie thee, Malvolio.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.l: Madam, I will.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: I do I know not what, and fear to find
Mine eye too great a flatterer for my mind.
Fate, show thy force. Ourselves we do not owe.
What is decreed must be, and be this so.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p:
Will you stay no longer? Nor will you not that
I go with you?

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.p:
By your patience, no. My stars shine darkly
over me. The malignancy of my fate might perhaps
distemper yours. Therefore I shall crave of you your
leave that I may bear my evils alone. It were a bad
recompense for your love to lay any of them on you.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p:
Let me yet know of you whither you are
bound.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.p:
No, sooth, sir. My determinate voyage is
mere extravagancy. But I perceive in you so excellent
a touch of modesty that you will not extort
from me what I am willing to keep in. Therefore it
charges me in manners the rather to express myself.
You must know of me, then, Antonio, my name
is Sebastian, which I called Roderigo. My father was
that Sebastian of Messaline whom I know you have
heard of. He left behind him myself and a sister,
both born in an hour. If the heavens had been
pleased, would we had so ended! But you, sir,
altered that, for some hour before you took me
from the breach of the sea was my sister drowned.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: Alas the day!

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.p:
A lady, sir, though it was said she much
resembled me, was yet of many accounted beautiful.
But though I could not with such estimable
wonder overfar believe that, yet thus far I will boldly
publish her: she bore a mind that envy could not but
call fair. She is drowned already, sir, with salt water,
though I seem to drown her remembrance again
with more.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: Pardon me, sir, your bad entertainment.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.p: O good Antonio, forgive me your trouble.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p:
If you will not murder me for my love, let me
be your servant.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.p:
If you will not undo what you have done—
that is, kill him whom you have recovered— desire
it not. Fare you well at once. My bosom is full of
kindness, and I am yet so near the manners of my
mother that, upon the least occasion more, mine
eyes will tell tales of me. I am bound to the Count
Orsino’s court. Farewell.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: The gentleness of all the gods go with thee!
I have many enemies in Orsino’s court,
Else would I very shortly see thee there.
But come what may, I do adore thee so
That danger shall seem sport, and I will go.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter Viola and Malvolio, at several doors.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
Were not you even now with the Countess
Olivia?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
Even now, sir. On a moderate pace I have since
arrived but hither.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
She returns this ring to you, sir. You might
have saved me my pains to have taken it away
yourself. She adds, moreover, that you should put
your lord into a desperate assurance she will none
of him. And one thing more, that you be never so
hardy to come again in his affairs unless it be to
report your lord’s taking of this. Receive it so.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: She took the ring of me. I’ll none of it.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
Come, sir, you peevishly threw it to her, and
her will is it should be so returned.

If it be worth stooping for, there it
lies in your eye; if not, be it his that finds it.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: I left no ring with her. What means this lady?
Fortune forbid my outside have not charmed her!
She made good view of me, indeed so much
That methought her eyes had lost her tongue,
For she did speak in starts distractedly.
She loves me, sure! The cunning of her passion
Invites me in this churlish messenger.
None of my lord’s ring? Why, he sent her none!
I am the man. If it be so, as ’tis,
Poor lady, she were better love a dream.
Disguise, I see thou art a wickedness
Wherein the pregnant enemy does much.
How easy is it for the proper false
In women’s waxen hearts to set their forms!
Alas, our frailty is the cause, not we,
For such as we are made of, such we be.
How will this fadge? My master loves her dearly,
And I, poor monster, fond as much on him,
And she, mistaken, seems to dote on me.
What will become of this? As I am man,
My state is desperate for my master’s love.
As I am woman ( now, alas the day!),
What thriftless sighs shall poor Olivia breathe!
O Time, thou must untangle this, not I.
It is too hard a knot for me t’ untie.

div.head: Scene 3
div.stage: Enter Sir Toby and Sir Andrew.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Approach, Sir Andrew. Not to be abed after
midnight is to be up betimes, and “ diluculo surgere,”
thou know’st—

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
Nay, by my troth, I know not. But I know to
be up late is to be up late.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
A false conclusion. I hate it as an unfilled can. To
be up after midnight and to go to bed then, is early,
so that to go to bed after midnight is to go to bed
betimes. Does not our lives consist of the four
elements?

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
Faith, so they say, but I think it rather consists
of eating and drinking.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Thou ’rt a scholar. Let us therefore eat and
drink. Marian, I say, a stoup of wine!

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Here comes the Fool, i’ faith.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
How now, my hearts? Did you never see the
picture of “ We Three”?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Welcome, ass! Now let’s have a catch.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
By my troth, the Fool has an excellent breast.
I had rather than forty shillings I had such a leg,
and so sweet a breath to sing, as the Fool has.— In
sooth, thou wast in very gracious fooling last night
when thou spok’st of Pigrogromitus of the Vapians
passing the equinoctial of Queubus. ’Twas very
good, i’ faith. I sent thee sixpence for thy leman.
Hadst it?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
I did impeticos thy gratillity, for Malvolio’s nose
is no whipstock, my lady has a white hand, and the
Myrmidons are no bottle-ale houses.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
Excellent! Why, this is the best fooling when
all is done. Now, a song!

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Come on, there is
sixpence for you. Let’s have a song.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
There’s a testril of
me, too. If one knight give a—

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Would you have a love song or a song of good
life?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: A love song, a love song.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Ay, ay, I care not for good life.

lg.l: O mistress mine, where are you roaming?
O, stay and hear! Your truelove’s coming,
That can sing both high and low.
Trip no further, pretty sweeting.
Journeys end in lovers meeting,
Every wise man’s son doth know.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Excellent good, i’ faith!

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Good, good.

lg.l: What is love? ’Tis not hereafter.
Present mirth hath present laughter.
What’s to come is still unsure.
In delay there lies no plenty,
Then come kiss me, sweet and twenty.
Youth’s a stuff will not endure.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: A mellifluous voice, as I am true knight.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: A contagious breath.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Very sweet and contagious, i’ faith.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
To hear by the nose, it is dulcet in contagion.
But shall we make the welkin dance indeed? Shall
we rouse the night owl in a catch that will draw
three souls out of one weaver? Shall we do that?

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
An you love me, let’s do ’t. I am dog at a
catch.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: By ’r Lady, sir, and some dogs will catch well.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
Most certain. Let our catch be “ Thou
Knave.”

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
“ Hold thy peace, thou knave,” knight? I shall be
constrained in ’t to call thee “ knave,” knight.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
’Tis not the first time I have constrained one
to call me “ knave.” Begin, Fool. It begins “ Hold
thy peace.”

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: I shall never begin if I hold my peace.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Good, i’ faith. Come, begin.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
What a caterwauling do you keep here! If my
lady have not called up her steward Malvolio and
bid him turn you out of doors, never trust me.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
My lady’s a Cataian, we are politicians, Malvolio’s
a Peg-a-Ramsey, and Sings. Three merry men be
we. Am not I consanguineous? Am I not of her
blood? Tillyvally! “ Lady”! Sings. There dwelt a man
in Babylon, lady, lady.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: Beshrew me, the knight’s in admirable fooling.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
Ay, he does well enough if he be disposed,
and so do I, too. He does it with a better grace, but
I do it more natural.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: O’ the twelfth day of December—

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: For the love o’ God, peace!

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
My masters, are you mad? Or what are you?
Have you no wit, manners, nor honesty but to
gabble like tinkers at this time of night? Do you
make an ale-house of my lady’s house, that you
squeak out your coziers’ catches without any mitigation
or remorse of voice? Is there no respect of
place, persons, nor time in you?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: We did keep time, sir, in our catches. Sneck up!

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
Sir Toby, I must be round with you. My lady
bade me tell you that, though she harbors you as her
kinsman, she’s nothing allied to your disorders. If
you can separate yourself and your misdemeanors,
you are welcome to the house; if not, an it would
please you to take leave of her, she is very willing to
bid you farewell.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Farewell, dear heart, since I must needs be gone.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: Nay, good Sir Toby.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: His eyes do show his days are almost done.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p: Is ’t even so?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: But I will never die.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: Sir Toby, there you lie.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p: This is much credit to you.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Shall I bid him go?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: What an if you do?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Shall I bid him go, and spare not?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: O no, no, no, no, you dare not.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Out o’ tune, sir? You lie. Art any more than a
steward? Dost thou think, because thou art virtuous,
there shall be no more cakes and ale?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Yes, by Saint Anne, and ginger shall be hot i’ th’
mouth, too.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Thou ’rt i’ th’ right.— Go, sir, rub your chain
with crumbs.— A stoup of wine, Maria!

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
Mistress Mary, if you prized my lady’s favor
at anything more than contempt, you would not give
means for this uncivil rule. She shall know of it, by
this hand.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: Go shake your ears!

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
’Twere as good a deed as to drink when a
man’s a-hungry, to challenge him the field and
then to break promise with him and make a fool of
him.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Do ’t, knight. I’ll write thee a challenge. Or I’ll
deliver thy indignation to him by word of mouth.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
Sweet Sir Toby, be patient for tonight. Since the
youth of the Count’s was today with my lady, she is
much out of quiet. For Monsieur Malvolio, let me
alone with him. If I do not gull him into a nayword
and make him a common recreation, do not think I
have wit enough to lie straight in my bed. I know I
can do it.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Possess us, possess us, tell us something of him.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: Marry, sir, sometimes he is a kind of puritan.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: O, if I thought that, I’d beat him like a dog!

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
What, for being a puritan? Thy exquisite reason,
dear knight?

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
I have no exquisite reason for ’t, but I have
reason good enough.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
The devil a puritan that he is, or anything
constantly but a time-pleaser; an affectioned ass
that cons state without book and utters it by great
swaths; the best persuaded of himself, so crammed,
as he thinks, with excellencies, that it is his grounds
of faith that all that look on him love him. And on
that vice in him will my revenge find notable cause
to work.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: What wilt thou do?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
I will drop in his way some obscure epistles of
love, wherein by the color of his beard, the shape of
his leg, the manner of his gait, the expressure of his
eye, forehead, and complexion, he shall find himself
most feelingly personated. I can write very like my
lady your niece; on a forgotten matter, we can
hardly make distinction of our hands.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Excellent! I smell a device.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: I have ’t in my nose, too.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
He shall think, by the letters that thou wilt drop,
that they come from my niece, and that she’s in
love with him.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: My purpose is indeed a horse of that color.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: And your horse now would make him an ass.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: Ass, I doubt not.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: O, ’twill be admirable!

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
Sport royal, I warrant you. I know my physic
will work with him. I will plant you two, and let the
Fool make a third, where he shall find the letter.
Observe his construction of it. For this night, to bed,
and dream on the event. Farewell.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Good night, Penthesilea.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Before me, she’s a good wench.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
She’s a beagle true bred, and one that adores
me. What o’ that?

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: I was adored once, too.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Let’s to bed, knight. Thou hadst need send for
more money.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
If I cannot recover your niece, I am a foul way
out.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Send for money, knight. If thou hast her not i’
th’ end, call me “ Cut.”

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
If I do not, never trust me, take it how you
will.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Come, come, I’ll go burn some sack. ’Tis too
late to go to bed now. Come, knight; come, knight.

div.head: Scene 4
div.stage: Enter Orsino, Viola, Curio, and others.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: Give me some music. Music plays. Now, good morrow, friends.—
Now, good Cesario, but that piece of song,
That old and antique song we heard last night.
Methought it did relieve my passion much,
More than light airs and recollected terms
Of these most brisk and giddy-pacèd times.
Come, but one verse.

sp.speaker: CURIO
sp.p:
He is not here, so please your Lordship, that
should sing it.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.p: Who was it?

sp.speaker: CURIO
sp.p:
Feste the jester, my lord, a Fool that the Lady
Olivia’s father took much delight in. He is about
the house.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: Seek him out Curio exits, and play the tune the while.
To Viola. Come hither, boy. If ever thou shalt love,
In the sweet pangs of it remember me,
For such as I am, all true lovers are,
Unstaid and skittish in all motions else
Save in the constant image of the creature
That is beloved. How dost thou like this tune?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: It gives a very echo to the seat
Where love is throned.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: Thou dost speak masterly.
My life upon ’t, young though thou art, thine eye
Hath stayed upon some favor that it loves.
Hath it not, boy?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: A little, by your favor.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: What kind of woman is ’t?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: Of your complexion.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: She is not worth thee, then. What years, i’ faith?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: About your years, my lord.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: Too old, by heaven. Let still the woman take
An elder than herself. So wears she to him;
So sways she level in her husband’s heart.
For, boy, however we do praise ourselves,
Our fancies are more giddy and unfirm,
More longing, wavering, sooner lost and worn,
Than women’s are.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: I think it well, my lord.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: Then let thy love be younger than thyself,
Or thy affection cannot hold the bent.
For women are as roses, whose fair flower,
Being once displayed, doth fall that very hour.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: And so they are. Alas, that they are so,
To die even when they to perfection grow!

div.stage: Enter Curio and Feste, the Fool.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: O, fellow, come, the song we had last night.—
Mark it, Cesario. It is old and plain;
The spinsters and the knitters in the sun
And the free maids that weave their thread with bones
Do use to chant it. It is silly sooth,
And dallies with the innocence of love
Like the old age.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: Are you ready, sir?

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.p: Ay, prithee, sing.

div.label: The Song.

lg.l: Come away, come away, death,
And in sad cypress let me be laid.
Fly away, fly away, breath,
I am slain by a fair cruel maid.
My shroud of white, stuck all with yew,
O, prepare it!
My part of death, no one so true
Did share it.
Not a flower, not a flower sweet
On my black coffin let there be strown;
Not a friend, not a friend greet
My poor corpse where my bones shall be thrown.
A thousand thousand sighs to save,
Lay me, O, where
Sad true lover never find my grave
To weep there.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.p: There’s for thy pains.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: No pains, sir. I take pleasure in singing, sir.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.p: I’ll pay thy pleasure, then.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Truly sir, and pleasure will be paid, one time or
another.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.p: Give me now leave to leave thee.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Now the melancholy god protect thee and the
tailor make thy doublet of changeable taffeta, for thy
mind is a very opal. I would have men of such
constancy put to sea, that their business might be
everything and their intent everywhere, for that’s it
that always makes a good voyage of nothing.
Farewell.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: Let all the rest give place.
sp.stage: All but Orsino and Viola exit.
sp.l: Once more, Cesario,
Get thee to yond same sovereign cruelty.
Tell her my love, more noble than the world,
Prizes not quantity of dirty lands.
The parts that Fortune hath bestowed upon her,
Tell her, I hold as giddily as Fortune.
But ’tis that miracle and queen of gems
That nature pranks her in attracts my soul.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: But if she cannot love you, sir—

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: I cannot be so answered.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: Sooth, but you must.
Say that some lady, as perhaps there is,
Hath for your love as great a pang of heart
As you have for Olivia. You cannot love her;
You tell her so. Must she not then be answered?

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: There is no woman’s sides
Can bide the beating of so strong a passion
As love doth give my heart; no woman’s heart
So big, to hold so much; they lack retention.
Alas, their love may be called appetite,
No motion of the liver but the palate,
That suffer surfeit, cloyment, and revolt;
But mine is all as hungry as the sea,
And can digest as much. Make no compare
Between that love a woman can bear me
And that I owe Olivia.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: Ay, but I know—

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: What dost thou know?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: Too well what love women to men may owe.
In faith, they are as true of heart as we.
My father had a daughter loved a man
As it might be, perhaps, were I a woman,
I should your Lordship.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: And what’s her history?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: A blank, my lord. She never told her love,
But let concealment, like a worm i’ th’ bud,
Feed on her damask cheek. She pined in thought,
And with a green and yellow melancholy
She sat like Patience on a monument,
Smiling at grief. Was not this love indeed?
We men may say more, swear more, but indeed
Our shows are more than will; for still we prove
Much in our vows but little in our love.

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: But died thy sister of her love, my boy?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: I am all the daughters of my father’s house,
And all the brothers, too— and yet I know not.
Sir, shall I to this lady?

sp.speaker: ORSINO
sp.l: Ay, that’s the theme.
To her in haste. Give her this jewel. Say
My love can give no place, bide no denay.

div.stage: He hands her a jewel and they exit.

div.head: Scene 5
div.stage: Enter Sir Toby, Sir Andrew, and Fabian.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Come thy ways, Signior Fabian.

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p:
Nay, I’ll come. If I lose a scruple of this sport,
let me be boiled to death with melancholy.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Wouldst thou not be glad to have the niggardly
rascally sheep-biter come by some notable shame?

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p:
I would exult, man. You know he brought me
out o’ favor with my lady about a bearbaiting here.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
To anger him, we’ll have the bear again, and we
will fool him black and blue, shall we not, Sir
Andrew?

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: An we do not, it is pity of our lives.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Here comes the little villain.— How now, my
metal of India?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
Get you all three into the boxtree. Malvolio’s
coming down this walk. He has been yonder i’ the
sun practicing behavior to his own shadow this half
hour. Observe him, for the love of mockery, for I
know this letter will make a contemplative idiot of
him. Close, in the name of jesting! They hide. Lie
thou there putting down the letter, for here comes
the trout that must be caught with tickling.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
’Tis but fortune, all is fortune. Maria once
told me she did affect me, and I have heard herself
come thus near, that should she fancy, it should be
one of my complexion. Besides, she uses me with a
more exalted respect than anyone else that follows
her. What should I think on ’t?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Here’s an overweening rogue.

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p:
O, peace! Contemplation makes a rare
turkeycock of him. How he jets under his advanced
plumes!

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: ’Slight, I could so beat the rogue!

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Peace, I say.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p: To be Count Malvolio.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Ah, rogue!

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Pistol him, pistol him!

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Peace, peace!

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
There is example for ’t. The lady of the
Strachy married the yeoman of the wardrobe.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Fie on him, Jezebel!

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p:
O, peace, now he’s deeply in. Look how
imagination blows him.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
Having been three months married to her,
sitting in my state—

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: O, for a stone-bow, to hit him in the eye!

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
Calling my officers about me, in my
branched velvet gown, having come from a daybed
where I have left Olivia sleeping—

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Fire and brimstone!

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p: O, peace, peace!

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
And then to have the humor of state; and
after a demure travel of regard, telling them I
know my place, as I would they should do theirs, to
ask for my kinsman Toby—

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Bolts and shackles!

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p: O, peace, peace, peace! Now, now.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
Seven of my people, with an obedient start,
make out for him. I frown the while, and perchance
wind up my watch, or play with my— some
rich jewel. Toby approaches; curtsies there to me—

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Shall this fellow live?

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p:
Though our silence be drawn from us
with cars, yet peace!

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
I extend my hand to him thus, quenching
my familiar smile with an austere regard of
control—

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
And does not Toby take you a blow o’ the
lips then?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
Saying, “ Cousin Toby, my fortunes, having
cast me on your niece, give me this prerogative of
speech—”

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: What, what?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p: “ You must amend your drunkenness.”

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Out, scab!

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p:
Nay, patience, or we break the sinews
of our plot!

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
“ Besides, you waste the treasure of your
time with a foolish knight—”

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: That’s me, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p: “ One Sir Andrew.”

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
I knew ’twas I, for many do call me
fool.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
What employment have
we here?

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p: Now is the woodcock near the gin.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
O, peace, and the spirit of humors intimate
reading aloud to him.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
By my life, this is my
lady’s hand! These be her very c’s, her u’s, and her
t’s, and thus she makes her great P’s. It is in
contempt of question her hand.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Her c’s, her u’s, and her t’s. Why that?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
To the unknown beloved, this, and my
good wishes— Her very phrases! By your leave, wax.
Soft. And the impressure her Lucrece, with which
she uses to seal— ’tis my lady!
To whom should this be?

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p: This wins him, liver and all.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO

lg.l: Jove knows I love,
But who?
Lips, do not move;
No man must know.

sp.p:
“ No man must know.” What follows? The numbers
altered. “ No man must know.” If this should be
thee, Malvolio!

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Marry, hang thee, brock!

lg.l: I may command where I adore,
But silence, like a Lucrece knife,
With bloodless stroke my heart doth gore;
M. O. A. I. doth sway my life.

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p: A fustian riddle!

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Excellent wench, say I.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
“ M. O. A. I. doth sway my life.” Nay, but first
let me see, let me see, let me see.

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p:
What dish o’ poison has she dressed
him!

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
And with what wing the staniel checks
at it!

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
“ I may command where I adore.” Why, she
may command me; I serve her; she is my lady. Why,
this is evident to any formal capacity. There is no
obstruction in this. And the end— what should that
alphabetical position portend? If I could make that
resemble something in me! Softly! “ M. O. A. I.”—

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
O, ay, make up that.— He is now at a cold
scent.

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p:
Sowter will cry upon ’t for all this,
though it be as rank as a fox.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
“ M”— Malvolio. “ M”— why, that begins
my name!

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p:
Did not I say he would work it out? The
cur is excellent at faults.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
“ M.” But then there is no consonancy in
the sequel that suffers under probation. “ A” should
follow, but “ O” does.

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p: And “ O” shall end, I hope.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Ay, or I’ll cudgel him and make him cry
“ O.”

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p: And then “ I” comes behind.

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p:
Ay, an you had any eye behind you, you
might see more detraction at your heels than fortunes
before you.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
“ M. O. A. I.” This simulation is not as the
former, and yet to crush this a little, it would bow
to me, for every one of these letters are in my name.
Soft, here follows prose.
He reads. If this fall into thy hand, revolve. In my
stars I am above thee, but be not afraid of greatness.
Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and
some have greatness thrust upon ’em. Thy fates open
their hands. Let thy blood and spirit embrace them.
And, to inure thyself to what thou art like to be, cast
thy humble slough and appear fresh. Be opposite with
a kinsman, surly with servants. Let thy tongue tang
arguments of state. Put thyself into the trick of singularity.
She thus advises thee that sighs for thee.
Remember who commended thy yellow stockings and
wished to see thee ever cross-gartered. I say, remember.
Go to, thou art made, if thou desir’st to be so. If
not, let me see thee a steward still, the fellow of
servants, and not worthy to touch Fortune’s fingers.
Farewell. She that would alter services with thee,
The Fortunate-Unhappy.
Daylight and champian discovers not more! This is
open. I will be proud, I will read politic authors, I
will baffle Sir Toby, I will wash off gross acquaintance,
I will be point-devise the very man. I do not
now fool myself, to let imagination jade me; for
every reason excites to this, that my lady loves me.
She did commend my yellow stockings of late, she
did praise my leg being cross-gartered, and in this
she manifests herself to my love and, with a kind of
injunction, drives me to these habits of her liking. I
thank my stars, I am happy. I will be strange, stout,
in yellow stockings, and cross-gartered, even with
the swiftness of putting on. Jove and my stars be
praised! Here is yet a postscript.
He reads. Thou canst not choose but know who I
am. If thou entertain’st my love, let it appear in thy
smiling; thy smiles become thee well. Therefore in my
presence still smile, dear my sweet, I prithee.
Jove, I thank thee! I will smile. I will do everything
that thou wilt have me.

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p:
I will not give my part of this sport for a
pension of thousands to be paid from the Sophy.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: I could marry this wench for this device.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: So could I too.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
And ask no other dowry with her but such
another jest.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Nor I neither.

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p: Here comes my noble gull-catcher.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Wilt thou set thy foot o’ my neck?

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Or o’ mine either?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Shall I play my freedom at tray-trip and become
thy bondslave?

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: I’ faith, or I either?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Why, thou hast put him in such a dream that
when the image of it leaves him he must run mad.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: Nay, but say true, does it work upon him?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Like aqua vitae with a midwife.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
If you will then see the fruits of the sport,
mark his first approach before my lady. He will
come to her in yellow stockings, and ’tis a color
she abhors, and cross-gartered, a fashion she detests;
and he will smile upon her, which will now
be so unsuitable to her disposition, being addicted
to a melancholy as she is, that it cannot
but turn him into a notable contempt. If you will
see it, follow me.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
To the gates of Tartar, thou most excellent devil
of wit!

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: I’ll make one, too.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Viola and Feste, the Fool, playing a tabor.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
Save thee, friend, and thy music. Dost thou live
by thy tabor?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: No, sir, I live by the church.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: Art thou a churchman?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
No such matter, sir. I do live by the church, for I
do live at my house, and my house doth stand by the
church.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
So thou mayst say the king lies by a beggar if a
beggar dwell near him, or the church stands by thy
tabor if thy tabor stand by the church.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
You have said, sir. To see this age! A sentence is
but a chev’ril glove to a good wit. How quickly the
wrong side may be turned outward!

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
Nay, that’s certain. They that dally nicely with
words may quickly make them wanton.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
I would therefore my sister had had no name,
sir.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: Why, man?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Why, sir, her name’s a word, and to dally with
that word might make my sister wanton. But,
indeed, words are very rascals since bonds disgraced
them.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: Thy reason, man?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Troth, sir, I can yield you none without words,
and words are grown so false I am loath to prove
reason with them.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
I warrant thou art a merry fellow and car’st for
nothing.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Not so, sir. I do care for something. But in my
conscience, sir, I do not care for you. If that be to
care for nothing, sir, I would it would make you
invisible.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: Art not thou the Lady Olivia’s Fool?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
No, indeed, sir. The Lady Olivia has no folly. She
will keep no Fool, sir, till she be married, and Fools
are as like husbands as pilchers are to herrings: the
husband’s the bigger. I am indeed not her Fool but
her corrupter of words.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: I saw thee late at the Count Orsino’s.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Foolery, sir, does walk about the orb like the
sun; it shines everywhere. I would be sorry, sir, but
the Fool should be as oft with your master as with
my mistress. I think I saw your Wisdom there.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
Nay, an thou pass upon me, I’ll no more with
thee. Hold, there’s expenses for thee.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Now Jove, in his next commodity of hair, send
thee a beard!

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
By my troth I’ll tell thee, I am almost sick for
one, aside though I would not have it grow on my
chin.— Is thy lady within?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: Would not a pair of these have bred, sir?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: Yes, being kept together and put to use.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
I would play Lord Pandarus of Phrygia, sir, to
bring a Cressida to this Troilus.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: I understand you, sir. ’Tis well begged.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
The matter I hope is not great, sir, begging but a
beggar: Cressida was a beggar. My lady is within, sir.
I will conster to them whence you come. Who you
are and what you would are out of my welkin— I
might say “ element,” but the word is overworn.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: This fellow is wise enough to play the Fool,
And to do that well craves a kind of wit.
He must observe their mood on whom he jests,
The quality of persons, and the time,
And, like the haggard, check at every feather
That comes before his eye. This is a practice
As full of labor as a wise man’s art:
For folly that he wisely shows is fit;
But wise men, folly-fall’n, quite taint their wit.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Save you, gentleman.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: And you, sir.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Dieu vous garde, monsieur.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p: Et vous aussi. Votre serviteur!

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: I hope, sir, you are, and I am yours.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Will you encounter the house? My niece is
desirous you should enter, if your trade be to her.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
I am bound to your niece, sir; I mean, she is the
list of my voyage.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Taste your legs, sir; put them to motion.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
My legs do better understand me, sir, than I
understand what you mean by bidding me taste my
legs.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: I mean, to go, sir, to enter.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
I will answer you with gait and entrance— but
we are prevented.
sp.stage: Enter Olivia, and Maria, her Gentlewoman.
sp.p:
Most excellent accomplished lady, the heavens rain
odors on you!

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
That youth’s a rare courtier. “ Rain
odors,” well.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.p:
My matter hath no voice, lady, but to your own
most pregnant and vouchsafed ear.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
“ Odors,” “ pregnant,” and “ vouchsafed.”
I’ll get ’em all three all ready.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
Let the garden door be shut, and leave me to
my hearing.
sp.stage: Sir Toby, Sir Andrew, and Maria exit.
sp.p: Give me your hand, sir.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: My duty, madam, and most humble service.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: What is your name?

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: Cesario is your servant’s name, fair princess.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: My servant, sir? ’Twas never merry world
Since lowly feigning was called compliment.
You’re servant to the Count Orsino, youth.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: And he is yours, and his must needs be yours.
Your servant’s servant is your servant, madam.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: For him, I think not on him. For his thoughts,
Would they were blanks rather than filled with me.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughts
On his behalf.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: O, by your leave, I pray you.
I bade you never speak again of him.
But would you undertake another suit,
I had rather hear you to solicit that
Than music from the spheres.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: Dear lady—

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: Give me leave, beseech you. I did send,
After the last enchantment you did here,
A ring in chase of you. So did I abuse
Myself, my servant, and, I fear me, you.
Under your hard construction must I sit,
To force that on you in a shameful cunning
Which you knew none of yours. What might you think?
Have you not set mine honor at the stake
And baited it with all th’ unmuzzled thoughts
That tyrannous heart can think? To one of your receiving
Enough is shown. A cypress, not a bosom,
Hides my heart. So, let me hear you speak.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: I pity you.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: That’s a degree to love.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: No, not a grize, for ’tis a vulgar proof
That very oft we pity enemies.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: Why then methinks ’tis time to smile again.
O world, how apt the poor are to be proud!
If one should be a prey, how much the better
To fall before the lion than the wolf.
The clock upbraids me with the waste of time.
Be not afraid, good youth, I will not have you.
And yet when wit and youth is come to harvest,
Your wife is like to reap a proper man.
There lies your way, due west.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: Then westward ho!
Grace and good disposition attend your Ladyship.
You’ll nothing, madam, to my lord by me?

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: Stay. I prithee, tell me what thou think’st of me.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: That you do think you are not what you are.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: If I think so, I think the same of you.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: Then think you right. I am not what I am.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: I would you were as I would have you be.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: Would it be better, madam, than I am?
I wish it might, for now I am your fool.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: O, what a deal of scorn looks beautiful
In the contempt and anger of his lip!
A murd’rous guilt shows not itself more soon
Than love that would seem hid. Love’s night is noon.—
Cesario, by the roses of the spring,
By maidhood, honor, truth, and everything,
I love thee so, that, maugre all thy pride,
Nor wit nor reason can my passion hide.
Do not extort thy reasons from this clause,
For that I woo, thou therefore hast no cause;
But rather reason thus with reason fetter:
Love sought is good, but given unsought is better.

sp.speaker: VIOLA
sp.l: By innocence I swear, and by my youth,
I have one heart, one bosom, and one truth,
And that no woman has, nor never none
Shall mistress be of it, save I alone.
And so adieu, good madam. Nevermore
Will I my master’s tears to you deplore.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: Yet come again, for thou perhaps mayst move
That heart, which now abhors, to like his love.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter Sir Toby, Sir Andrew, and Fabian.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: No, faith, I’ll not stay a jot longer.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Thy reason, dear venom, give thy reason.

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p: You must needs yield your reason, Sir Andrew.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
Marry, I saw your niece do more favors to the
Count’s servingman than ever she bestowed upon
me. I saw ’t i’ th’ orchard.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Did she see thee the while, old boy? Tell me
that.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: As plain as I see you now.

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p:
This was a great argument of love in her toward
you.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: ’Slight, will you make an ass o’ me?

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p:
I will prove it legitimate, sir, upon the oaths of
judgment and reason.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
And they have been grand-jurymen since before
Noah was a sailor.

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p:
She did show favor to the youth in your sight
only to exasperate you, to awake your dormouse
valor, to put fire in your heart and brimstone in
your liver. You should then have accosted her, and
with some excellent jests, fire-new from the mint,
you should have banged the youth into dumbness.
This was looked for at your hand, and this was
balked. The double gilt of this opportunity you let
time wash off, and you are now sailed into the north
of my lady’s opinion, where you will hang like an
icicle on a Dutchman’s beard, unless you do redeem
it by some laudable attempt either of valor or
policy.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p:
An ’t be any way, it must be with valor, for
policy I hate. I had as lief be a Brownist as a
politician.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Why, then, build me thy fortunes upon the basis
of valor. Challenge me the Count’s youth to fight
with him. Hurt him in eleven places. My niece shall
take note of it, and assure thyself there is no
love-broker in the world can more prevail in man’s
commendation with woman than report of valor.

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p: There is no way but this, Sir Andrew.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Will either of you bear me a challenge to him?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Go, write it in a martial hand. Be curst and
brief. It is no matter how witty, so it be eloquent
and full of invention. Taunt him with the license of
ink. If thou “thou”-est him some thrice, it shall not
be amiss, and as many lies as will lie in thy sheet of
paper, although the sheet were big enough for the
bed of Ware in England, set ’em down. Go, about it.
Let there be gall enough in thy ink, though thou
write with a goose-pen, no matter. About it.

sp.speaker: ANDREW
sp.p: Where shall I find you?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: We’ll call thee at the cubiculo. Go.

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p: This is a dear manikin to you, Sir Toby.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
I have been dear to him, lad, some two thousand
strong or so.

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p:
We shall have a rare letter from him. But you’ll
not deliver ’t?

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p:
Never trust me, then. And by all means stir on
the youth to an answer. I think oxen and wainropes
cannot hale them together. For Andrew, if he were
opened and you find so much blood in his liver as
will clog the foot of a flea, I’ll eat the rest of th’
anatomy.

sp.speaker: FABIAN
sp.p:
And his opposite, the youth, bears in his visage
no great presage of cruelty.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Look where the youngest wren of mine comes.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
If you desire the spleen, and will laugh yourselves
into stitches, follow me. Yond gull Malvolio is
turned heathen, a very renegado; for there is no
Christian that means to be saved by believing rightly
can ever believe such impossible passages of grossness.
He’s in yellow stockings.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: And cross-gartered?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
Most villainously, like a pedant that keeps a
school i’ th’ church. I have dogged him like his
murderer. He does obey every point of the letter
that I dropped to betray him. He does smile his face
into more lines than is in the new map with the
augmentation of the Indies. You have not seen such
a thing as ’tis. I can hardly forbear hurling things at
him. I know my lady will strike him. If she do, he’ll
smile and take ’t for a great favor.

sp.speaker: TOBY
sp.p: Come, bring us, bring us where he is.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: I would not by my will have troubled you,
But, since you make your pleasure of your pains,
I will no further chide you.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: I could not stay behind you. My desire,
More sharp than filèd steel, did spur me forth;
And not all love to see you, though so much
As might have drawn one to a longer voyage,
But jealousy what might befall your travel,
Being skill-less in these parts, which to a stranger,
Unguided and unfriended, often prove
Rough and unhospitable. My willing love,
The rather by these arguments of fear,
Set forth in your pursuit.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: My kind Antonio,
I can no other answer make but thanks,
And thanks, and ever thanks; and oft good turns
Are shuffled off with such uncurrent pay.
But were my worth, as is my conscience, firm,
You should find better dealing. What’s to do?
Shall we go see the relics of this town?

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Tomorrow, sir. Best first go see your lodging.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: I am not weary, and ’tis long to night.
I pray you, let us satisfy our eyes
With the memorials and the things of fame
That do renown this city.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Would you’d pardon me.
I do not without danger walk these streets.
Once in a sea fight ’gainst the Count his galleys
I did some service, of such note indeed
That were I ta’en here it would scarce be answered.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Belike you slew great number of his people?

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Th’ offense is not of such a bloody nature,
Albeit the quality of the time and quarrel
Might well have given us bloody argument.
It might have since been answered in repaying
What we took from them, which, for traffic’s sake,
Most of our city did. Only myself stood out,
For which, if I be lapsèd in this place,
I shall pay dear.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Do not then walk too open.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: It doth not fit me. Hold, sir, here’s my purse.
In the south suburbs, at the Elephant,
Is best to lodge. I will bespeak our diet
Whiles you beguile the time and feed your knowledge
With viewing of the town. There shall you have me.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: Why I your purse?

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: Haply your eye shall light upon some toy
You have desire to purchase, and your store,
I think, is not for idle markets, sir.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: I’ll be your purse-bearer and leave you
For an hour.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.l: To th’ Elephant.

sp.speaker: SEBASTIAN
sp.l: I do remember.

div.head: Scene 4

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: I have sent after him. He says he’ll come.
How shall I feast him? What bestow of him?
For youth is bought more oft than begged or borrowed.
I speak too loud.—
Where’s Malvolio? He is sad and civil
And suits well for a servant with my fortunes.
Where is Malvolio?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
He’s coming, madam, but in very strange manner.
He is sure possessed, madam.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Why, what’s the matter? Does he rave?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
No, madam, he does nothing but smile. Your
Ladyship were best to have some guard about you if
he come, for sure the man is tainted in ’s wits.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.l: Go call him hither. Maria exits. I am as mad as he,
If sad and merry madness equal be.
How now, Malvolio?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.l: Sweet lady, ho, ho!

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
Smil’st thou? I sent for thee upon a sad
occasion.

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
Sad, lady? I could be sad. This does make
some obstruction in the blood, this cross-gartering,
but what of that? If it please the eye of one, it is
with me as the very true sonnet is: “ Please one, and
please all.”

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
Why, how dost thou, man? What is the matter
with thee?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
Not black in my mind, though yellow in my
legs. It did come to his hands, and commands shall
be executed. I think we do know the sweet Roman
hand.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Wilt thou go to bed, Malvolio?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
To bed? “ Ay, sweetheart, and I’ll come to
thee.”

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
God comfort thee! Why dost thou smile so, and
kiss thy hand so oft?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p: How do you, Malvolio?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
At your request? Yes, nightingales answer
daws!

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.p:
Why appear you with this ridiculous boldness
before my lady?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
“ Be not afraid of greatness.” ’Twas well
writ.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: What mean’st thou by that, Malvolio?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p: “ Some are born great—”

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p: “ Some achieve greatness—”

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: What sayst thou?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
“ And some have greatness thrust upon
them.”

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Heaven restore thee!

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
“ Remember who commended thy yellow
stockings—”

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Thy yellow stockings?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p: “ And wished to see thee cross-gartered.”

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Cross-gartered?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p:
“ Go to, thou art made, if thou desir’st to be
so—”

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Am I made?

sp.speaker: MALVOLIO
sp.p: “ If not, let me see thee a servant still.”

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p: Why, this is very midsummer madness!

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p:
Madam, the young gentleman of the Count
Orsino’s is returned. I could hardly entreat him
back. He attends your Ladyship’s pleasure.

sp.speaker: OLIVIA
sp.p:
I’ll come to him. Servant exits. Good Maria, let
this fellow be looked to. Where’s my Cousin Toby?
Let some of my people have a special care of him. I
